title: AIX Ventures Gathers Top AI Talent to Invest in Startups; Co-founder and Investment Partner Richard Socher, former chief scientist at Salesforce.com, says deep technical expertise is critical for investors in AI
text:
The fund's name means "AI plus X," Mr. Socher said. "X is a parameter of a different industry and AI is kind of changing all these industries," he said.

The team also includes Pieter Abbeel, co-founder of robotics AI startup Covariant; Anthony Goldbloom, co-founder of machine-learning competitions startup Kaggle, now a subsidiary of Google; and Christopher Manning, director of the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory.

The firm, founded last year, has already made 15 new deals and transferred 25 of Mr. Socher's earlier investments into the fund.

About a third of its portfolio so far has been in healthcare and life sciences, such as Atomic.ai, which is involved in new molecule design, and Athelas, maker of an at-home blood test.

Mr. Socher said that AI advances in natural-language processing, for example, are especially exciting in life sciences.

"Instead of predicting the next English word, you can predict the next protein," he said, adding that that capability opens up new opportunities in drug discovery.

AIX also invests in other sectors, including enterprise software, manufacturing and consumer. Its portfolio companies include weather-prediction startup Atmo, human-machine interface company Wispr AI Inc. and Time By Ping Inc., which automates legal billing.

San Francisco-based AIX raised capital from funds including Bain Capital Ventures, Foundation Capital, Khosla Ventures, Lux Capital and Village Global.

In an unusual structure for a venture firm, investment partners at AIX are working at the fund part-time, sourcing and evaluating deals, as well as acting as mentors to founders, Mr. Socher said.

AIX also has an operating team responsible for evaluating deals and helping companies post-investment. That's led by co-founder and General Partner Shaun Johnson, previously a vice president of engineering at startup Lilt, who's fully dedicated to AIX. On the operations team, Fang Yuan, a former investor at Baidu Ventures, is a part-time general operating partner.

This structure is best to provide support to AI startups that seek investors with deep technical expertise, Mr. Socher said. Maintaining such expertise in a field that moves as fast as AI research requires being immersed in it, he said, and that's why AIX Ventures' investment partners are keeping their other jobs.

"The best AI entrepreneurs want the top AI practitioners on their cap table," Mr. Socher said, adding, "to be a top practitioner, you can't be a full-time VC."

Write to Yuliya Chernova at yuliya.chernova@wsj.com
